text: <@U0677FXK8|mandeep> has joined the channel
is there any way to speed up gradle sync

I have put this in my gradle.build file 
compile 'com.google.android.gms:play-services:+'
    compile 'com.google.android.gms:play-services-identity:+'

when i build , it fails
with the message

Error:Execution failed for task ':app:dexDebug'.
> com.android.ide.common.process.ProcessException: org.gradle.process.internal.ExecException: Process 'command '/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_75.jdk/Contents/Home/bin/java'' finished with non-zero exit value 2
any clue ?
Shouldn’t it be enough to include either? First one is the catch-all for play services, no?
Hey <@U04TK850N>
is passing an intent to a constructor expensive?
It is probably not more or less expensive than passing it to a method
i am asking bec whenever i put a debug point on it and evaluates the expression , it just stucks forever
Method breakpoints are always slow
AS warns you about it
it works for everything except intent breakpoint
How much extra data does it have?
And do you really need the full intent?
sry, brb
i need to start a activity
so i think i need it full
one more thing
How can i check if intent has context.
Intent() vs Intent(this,Activity.class)

Hey guys I have one question… Our team is  having a little discussion about what is the best approach on the situation below.
We have a simple app with a map some locations a login and some info views. To provide the data for each view we have to call a webservice also developed by us… The question is, each time the user open the app we fill the database with ALL the data for each view OR for each view we call the webservice and get data for the called view…
Google has removed plus from com.google.android.gms package.. what is the new package they introduced for plus ?
i am integrating  google login ...
using the dependency com.google.android.gms:play-services-identity:+
error: package com.google.android.gms.plus does not exist
<@U04UEGMR4>: ```com.google.android.gms:play-services-plus:7.5.0```
<@U04U18ANZ>: I don’t think Intent implements Context. For your initial question I don’t think it will be a performance issue, but you can always use the profiling tool to check how long it takes
Actually i have a ViewPager Adapter
and in instantiateItem() object
i am implementing a click listener
on which it takes me to a new Activity.
so i thought to pass intent to it
Why not create the Intent onClick?
i didn't get it
I mean, create the Intent in the OnClickListener
yes.
i thought to create only ViewPager adapter and call it from various places
just pass the intent
Is it the same intent for each item?
no
Then it might be a bit too much to have to pass X Intents
You could instead have an Interface that calls back into the Activity that uses the Adapter which can then create the desired Intent on demand
so what i did was to implement an interface in the adapter
yes
now there is a problem in it
my One of the activities has 2 Viewpager
now it again becomes messy
how would i know that which one is clicked
my original implementation is with interface only
u got my point?
Give them unique tags or something
how
Well, in adapter you call your interface with some parameter, no? Make that parameter know which ViewPager it is
It’s kinda hard to guess your implementation :smile:
i can show you my implementation
<@U04U18ANZ|shobhit> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/shobhit/F067F8NMP/viewpageradapter.java|ViewPagerAdapter>

            Intent intent = new Intent(getApplicationContext(), Activity.class);
            intent.setFlags(Intent.FLAG_ACTIVITY_NEW_TASK);
            getApplicationContext().startActivity(intent);

text: But that is just always the same Intent?
yes
but this is the case where activity has single viewpager
now what will happen when activity has two viewpager?
now for a single instance of imageViewClickHandler()
Both will call that handler
yes.
but i need it with diff intents
Then in your Adapter constructor add a param like viewPagerTag, set it to „VIEWPAGER_1“ or „VIEWPAGER_2“ (or whatever), and pass that tag in your clickHanlder interface
Then you know which one got clicked
Can it be done with callback
sure
it would be great if you can tell me
i dnt know how to use Callbacks
i looked into handler.Callback
but it takes only Message
it’s Interface, basic Java concept
gah
see how the last one gets a Context?
(that is a different thing here, but the interface works the same way for you)
`imageViewClickHandler(String viewPagerTag)`
that is what you need to put into `ClickHandlerViewPager`
got it
And you should btw make sure mContext actually implemements that interface, so you don’t end up with a ClassCastException somehow
like `if (mContext instanceof ClickHandlerViewPager)`
yes that has been done already
check in the code

<@U054A24ET>: the only way to get gradle sync to go faster (other than making sure you are on 2.4 or higher) is to throw a processor at it that has a really high single core performance and the faster your disk storage the better. The latest rmbp crushes it for instance.
Or you can turn on offline mode

<@U0548MM6B>: That does not help me with my work flow unfortunately. We have about 40 different internal libraries so most of my work everyday is throwing up snapshots then testing then deploying releases
deploying snapshots to maven local would alleviate that somewhat but not entirely given our process

<@U063EMGDQ>: How much data are we talking about? If its just a few KB in total and is unlikely to change, yes grab it all in one request. If the data is likely to change a lot, you should use one of the many http libraries and make sure you are using the request caching that way the library configuration can determine when to hit the server and when to hit local storage. This also permits your webserver to define per request how long the data is good for which can be really useful. <@U0542GLTE> has a lot of experience in this department.
you could try parallel processing if your project is viable for it
<@U055GGAHS>:  oh damn man, hard to believe you can speed it up any other way
if you’ve tried everything, and using 2.4
2.4 was a massive increase in speed for me
just throwing more power at it :confused:
but so was throwing tons of power at it
not using windows made a big difference too
our build server is a xeon and my rmbp is now faster than it by a good 50%-70% on most builds
Im using gradle 2.2.1 :open_mouth:
yeah its the default when you create a project
gradle-wrapper.properties is where you “upgrade” to gradle 2.4 right?
correct
set that to 2.4-bin
you can do -all if you want to see samples and everything else

<@U055GGAHS>: Thanks for the information… Yes the data will change a lot I think… Do you recommend any good libraries for Http Requests? until now I build all the views and next week I will implement the controllers and services. The famous ones it is volley and okhttp I think. 
Other question, should I use some library for the localstorage? I am thinking about using the SQLite database, the werservices are made with node.js and mongodb
do not use volley =P. OkHTTP is good but I prefer ION. <https://github.com/koush/ion>

text: Again, <@U0542GLTE> would be the better one to ask for this stuff
For storage again that depends on the data and how you need to use it
I personally make heavy use of mapdb and will do anything I can to avoid using sqlite
I'm in the car. I'll read this in a minute
Nice I will take a look, thanks for the references :wink:
bluntly asked, what is the advantage to my asynctasks that use HttpUrlConnection?
thats a two part issue
async tasks are not recommended for networking requests
1) Don’t use async task if it will need to hold reference to a view

2) Manually managing networking is painful and 9/10 you are going to make a mistake without knowing it. Furthermore libraries abstract issues and offer more support for features you may need in the future, additionally they properly handle all request codes, timeouts, caching, etc
uh, hold on, not asynctasks but a service
I’m not the smartest one
its fine.. still the same don’t manually build http connections unless you are really sure you know what you are doing/need
I like doing network requests on intentservices
as that opens up a separate thread
that’s not really true
Hm, I might try ion on a little project I’ve been building
the initial service creation is on your main thread and is heavy
if possible you should avoid it, additionally libraries like ion use only one thread and make heavy use of NIO so multiple connections can run concurrently with just that one thread
interesting
i used to use robospice, but it looks like they're not updating it much these days
you should really only use services if you have a business case for it like sharing data between processes and apps
OkHttp and ION aren't really comparable. OkHttp is more like AsyncAndroid to ION. RetroFit + Picasso would be the equivalent to ION
And yeah, intentservices are not a good idea, neither are asynctasks
<http://slides.com/austinmusice/androidnetworking#/>

attachments.title: Networking With Android by Austin Musice
attachments.fallback: Slides: Networking With Android by Austin Musice
